elements.content: A family of six triple-decker complexes, {(MX)2[(pz)4]3} (Hpz = 4-nitropyrazole, MX = NaCl, 1; NaBr, 2; NaI, 3; KCl, 4; KBr, 5, and KI, 6), exhibiting inclusion of halides into inverse 12-metallacrown-4 [inv-(12-MCCu(I),pz-4)] array has been realized. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography of each compound reveals a common structural feature consisting of four CuI ions bonded by four pz to form a square metallomacrocycle comprising four metal centers and eight N atoms, thus giving an inv-[12-MCCu(I),pz-4] motif. Two halides are sandwiched by three inv-[12-MCCu(I),pz-4] to form triple-deckers that are further extended in an offset stacking mode by ligand-unsupported cuprophilicity interactions to form a one-dimensional chain structure. Halides are attached to six CuI centers with weak CuI···halogen interaction, resembling anion templates. High-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry reveals that the predominant fragments corresponding to a half of the triple-decker structures of 1–3 exist in solution. Compounds 4, 5, and 6 showed excellent electrocatalytic activities toward the reduction of nitrite and can also be used as selective “turn-off” sensors for Ag­(I) in water. The present results will be helpful for the future design and synthesis of functional inverse metallacrowns and their multiple-decker complexes.
elements.clean_text: A family of six triple-decker complexes, {(MX)2[(pz)4]3} (Hpz = 4-nitropyrazole, MX = NaCl, 1; NaBr, 2; NaI, 3; KCl, 4; KBr, 5, and KI, 6), exhibiting inclusion of halides into inverse 12-metallacrown-4 [inv-(12-MCCu(I),pz-4)] array has been realized. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography of each compound reveals a common structural feature consisting of four CuI ions bonded by four pz to form a square metallomacrocycle comprising four metal centers and eight N atoms, thus giving an inv-[12-MCCu(I),pz-4] motif. Two halides are sandwiched by three inv-[12-MCCu(I),pz-4] to form triple-deckers that are further extended in an offset stacking mode by ligand-unsupported cuprophilicity interactions to form a one-dimensional chain structure. Halides are attached to six CuI centers with weak CuI⋅⋅⋅halogen interaction, resembling anion templates. High-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry reveals that the predominant fragments corresponding to a half of the triple-decker structures of 1-3 exist in solution. Compounds 4, 5, and 6 showed excellent electrocatalytic activities toward the reduction of nitrite and can also be used as selective "turn-off" sensors for Ag(I) in water. The present results will be helpful for the future design and synthesis of functional inverse metallacrowns and their multiple-decker complexes.

elements.content: Because the macrocyclic crown ethers were first synthesized by the Nobel Laureate Pedersen, cavity-accessible molecules have attracted chemists owing to their capability to bind cations and anions, trap transient species, and act as a molecular flask for chemical reactions. Their inorganic analogues, metallacrowns, have similar skeletons and adjustable cavities, but they incorporate metal atoms into them, which, as a result, produced several additional functional properties such as single-molecule magnet, bioactivity, catalysis, and molecular recognition from either cavity or metal center or both. Over recent years, abundant metallacrowns constructed using various metals and ligands have been reported and were comprehensively reviewed by Pecoraro in 2007. Among the ligands used in the construction of metallacrowns, pyrazole and its derivatives are the least studied, although they have electronically similar neighboring N atoms that can replace adjacent methylene carbon atoms of a crown ether that could clamp more than one metal atom in close proximity. Although some polynuclear coinage complexes with pyrazole or its derivatives have been reported, most of them are the trinuclear 9-MCCu/Ag/Au-3 complexes. There are sporadic tetranuclear 12-MCCu-4 complexes, such as [Cu­(dppz)]4 (Hdppz = 3,5-diphenylpyrazole) observed, but the majority are not planar molecules but adopt a saddlelike conformation (D 2 point symmetry) and planar 4-fold 12-MCCu-4 complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Because the macrocyclic crown ethers were first synthesized by the Nobel Laureate Pedersen, cavity-accessible molecules have attracted chemists owing to their capability to bind cations and anions, trap transient species, and act as a molecular flask for chemical reactions. Their inorganic analogues, metallacrowns, have similar skeletons and adjustable cavities, but they incorporate metal atoms into them, which, as a result, produced several additional functional properties such as single-molecule magnet, bioactivity, catalysis, and molecular recognition from either cavity or metal center or both. Over recent years, abundant metallacrowns constructed using various metals and ligands have been reported and were comprehensively reviewed by Pecoraro in 2007. Among the ligands used in the construction of metallacrowns, pyrazole and its derivatives are the least studied, although they have electronically similar neighboring N atoms that can replace adjacent methylene carbon atoms of a crown ether that could clamp more than one metal atom in close proximity. Although some polynuclear coinage complexes with pyrazole or its derivatives have been reported, most of them are the trinuclear 9-MCCu/Ag/Au-3 complexes. There are sporadic tetranuclear 12-MCCu-4 complexes, such as [Cu(dppz)]4 (Hdppz = 3,5-diphenylpyrazole) observed, but the majority are not planar molecules but adopt a saddlelike conformation (D 2 point symmetry) and planar 4-fold 12-MCCu-4 complexes.

elements.content: Multiple-decker structures in organometallic chemistry with the simplest example of ferrocene have been considerably developed for Ln­(III)-phthalocyaninato/porphyrinato sandwich complexes, which exhibited great potential in the fields of molecular magnets such as single-molecule magnets and single-ion magnets because of their unique coordination symmetry, resulting in very large magnetic anisotropy. Jiang and Kobayashi groups have reported several series of tetrapyrrole-sandwiched metal complexes from double- and triple-decker to the new quadruple- and quintuple-decker and even the largest sextuple-decker in this family to date. They attributed the formation of such complex multiple-deckers to the effective intramolecular π···π orbital overlapping from aromatic macrocyclic ligands, which largely limited the development of multiple-decker molecules owing to the scarcity of organic conjugate ligands. Although the advances of metallacrowns have cast new light on this research area, multiple-decker molecules built from them are still extremely rare. Burini and Fackler et al. first unmasked a double-decker Ag­{[Au­(bzim)]3}2 (bzim = 1-benzylimidazolate) with one Ag atom sandwiched by two 9-MCAu-3 units. Fujita et al. reported a cage-trapped triple-decker cluster constructed from three 9-MCAu-3 units followed by the uptake of two silver atoms between them. From the above results, we speculate that larger metallacrowns may not favor the formation of multiple-decker arrays because of the larger macrocyclic motifs, resulting in more distortion from planarity, as supported by some saddlelike 12-MCCu-4 geometries.
elements.clean_text: Multiple-decker structures in organometallic chemistry with the simplest example of ferrocene have been considerably developed for Ln(III)-phthalocyaninato/porphyrinato sandwich complexes, which exhibited great potential in the fields of molecular magnets such as single-molecule magnets and single-ion magnets because of their unique coordination symmetry, resulting in very large magnetic anisotropy. Jiang and Kobayashi groups have reported several series of tetrapyrrole-sandwiched metal complexes from double- and triple-decker to the new quadruple- and quintuple-decker and even the largest sextuple-decker in this family to date. They attributed the formation of such complex multiple-deckers to the effective intramolecular π⋅⋅⋅π orbital overlapping from aromatic macrocyclic ligands, which largely limited the development of multiple-decker molecules owing to the scarcity of organic conjugate ligands. Although the advances of metallacrowns have cast new light on this research area, multiple-decker molecules built from them are still extremely rare. Burini and Fackler et al. first unmasked a double-decker Ag{[Au(bzim)]3}2 (bzim = 1-benzylimidazolate) with one Ag atom sandwiched by two 9-MCAu-3 units. Fujita et al. reported a cage-trapped triple-decker cluster constructed from three 9-MCAu-3 units followed by the uptake of two silver atoms between them. From the above results, we speculate that larger metallacrowns may not favor the formation of multiple-decker arrays because of the larger macrocyclic motifs, resulting in more distortion from planarity, as supported by some saddlelike 12-MCCu-4 geometries.

elements.content: In this study, based on larger inverse 12-metallacrown-4 [inv-(12-MCCu(I),pz-4)] ([CuI(pz)]4), we realized the synthesis of a triple-decker complex from a novel planar metallacrown and halides (). Its fourfold symmetric structure highly resembles an inverse triple-decker Ln­(III)-phthalocyaninato/porphyrinato sandwich complex with the replacement of Ln­(III) by a halide and an organic ligand by a metallacrown. The synergetic effects from both electron-withdrawing nitro group and electron-donating halide template are responsible for the formation of such unusual triple-decker complexes. Moreover, solution stability, electrochemical behavior, electrocatalysis performance, and the silver ion sensing property were studied in details.
elements.clean_text: In this study, based on larger inverse 12-metallacrown-4 [inv-(12-MCCu(I),pz-4)] ([CuI(pz)]4), we realized the synthesis of a triple-decker complex from a novel planar metallacrown and halides (). Its fourfold symmetric structure highly resembles an inverse triple-decker Ln(III)-phthalocyaninato/porphyrinato sandwich complex with the replacement of Ln(III) by a halide and an organic ligand by a metallacrown. The synergetic effects from both electron-withdrawing nitro group and electron-donating halide template are responsible for the formation of such unusual triple-decker complexes. Moreover, solution stability, electrochemical behavior, electrocatalysis performance, and the silver ion sensing property were studied in details.

elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Organic 12-Crown-4 Ether and Its Inorganic Analogue, Inverse 12-Metallacrown-4. (b) Schematic Representation for the Assembly of Triple-Decker Array from 12-MCCu-4 (Gray Disk) and Halogen Ions (Green Ball)

elements.content: The metallacrown complexes were synthesized in mixed N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF)/ethanol (v/v = 1:5) solution by using a one-pot solvothermal reaction at 160 °C from CuII(BF4)2 and 4-nitropyrazole in the presence of different MX salts (MX = NaCl, 1; NaBr, 2; NaI, 3; KCl, 4; KBr, 5; and KI, 6). The resulting complexes were isolated in moderate yields (50–60%). In situ reduction of CuII to CuI is not uncommon as seen in many CuI coordination complexes. The MX salts have important influences on the final oxidation state of Cu in the products. A hexanuclear CuII cluster {[F@CuII 6(pz)9(OH)2(DMF)4(H2O)]·2DMF, 7} was isolated when NaF was used. Different substituted pyrazole ligands, such as pyrazole, 3,5-dimethyl-pyrazole, 3-methyl-pyrazole, 4-methyl-pyrazole, 4-chloro-pyrazole, 4-bromo-pyrazole, and 4-iodo-pyrazole, have been used in this system, but only unknown precipitates were formed after solvothermal reactions, which indicated that the substituent groups also impact the formation of triple-decker complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The metallacrown complexes were synthesized in mixed N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF)/ethanol (v/v = 1:5) solution by using a one-pot solvothermal reaction at 160 °C from CuII(BF4)2 and 4-nitropyrazole in the presence of different MX salts (MX = NaCl, 1; NaBr, 2; NaI, 3; KCl, 4; KBr, 5; and KI, 6). The resulting complexes were isolated in moderate yields (50-60%). In situ reduction of CuII to CuI is not uncommon as seen in many CuI coordination complexes. The MX salts have important influences on the final oxidation state of Cu in the products. A hexanuclear CuII cluster {[F@CuII 6(pz)9(OH)2(DMF)4(H2O)]⋅2DMF, 7} was isolated when NaF was used. Different substituted pyrazole ligands, such as pyrazole, 3,5-dimethyl-pyrazole, 3-methyl-pyrazole, 4-methyl-pyrazole, 4-chloro-pyrazole, 4-bromo-pyrazole, and 4-iodo-pyrazole, have been used in this system, but only unknown precipitates were formed after solvothermal reactions, which indicated that the substituent groups also impact the formation of triple-decker complexes.

elements.content: Compounds 1–6 have similar one-dimensional (1D) structure based on centrosymmetric triple-decker subunits, as evidenced by X-ray single-crystal determinations. Because of their structural similarity, only the structure of 1 is described in detail. For others, only where significant differences are present will be noted. Some key structural parameters of 1–6 are listed in for comparisons. Selected details of the data collection and structure refinements are listed in Table S1, and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2. The bond valence sum analysis for the Cu atoms in 1–6 indicated that their charge states are +1 (Table S3).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structures of 1-6 

Compounds 1-6 have similar one-dimensional (1D) structure based on centrosymmetric triple-decker subunits, as evidenced by X-ray single-crystal determinations. Because of their structural similarity, only the structure of 1 is described in detail. For others, only where significant differences are present will be noted. Some key structural parameters of 1-6 are listed in  for comparisons. Selected details of the data collection and structure refinements are listed in Table S1, and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2. The bond valence sum analysis for the Cu atoms in 1-6 indicated that their charge states are +1 (Table S3).

elements.content:
Selected Metric Parameters in the Crystal Structures of <bold>1–6</bold> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref>

Black ball is the centroid of every four CuI ions in one metallacrown. Green ball is the halogen ion and purple ball is the CuI ion.

The formula of 1 was written as {(NaCl)2[CuI 4(pz)4]3} to facilitate the understanding of its structure. The metallacrown [CuI 4(pz)4] has a neutral charge, and the sandwiched Cl– is charge-balanced by the linked Na+ at the periphery of a metallacrown to keep the overall charge neutral. As shown in a, four CuI and four pz– comprise a 12-membered metallomacrocycle, and the CuI atoms orient toward the center of a cavity, thus defining an inv-(12-MCCu(I),pz-4), which has a pseudo fourfold axis passing through the center of a metallacrown and gives an approximately square window. If weak CuI···Cl interaction is included, each CuI is in a T-shaped three-coordinate geometry completed by one Cl– and two N atoms of two different pz– ligands, making an average N–Cu–N angle of 158.2°. Such deviation from linearity should be pushed by Cl– in the perpendicular direction with respect to the N–Cu–N orientation. The T-shaped coordinate geometry of Cu­(I) has been widely observed in a biological protein such as hemocyanin and also several Cu­(I) coordination compounds. By contrast, the N–Cu–N angles in 7 tend to linearity [165.15(10)–179.60(11)°], which indicates that the stronger interaction between Cu and Cl/Br/I helps to stabilize the otherwise more constrained and thus less stable 12-MCCu(I),pz-4. The Cu–N bond distances vary from 1.868(5) to 1.882(5) Å. Four pz– ligands that are oriented in almost the same plane coincided with that built from four CuI centers. This geometry is substantially different from that of [Cu­(dppz)]4 (Hdppz = 3,5-diphenylpyrazole) with every two dppz ligands projected above and below the Cu4 ring, forming a saddlelike molecule. Four nitro groups point to the outside of the metallacrown and thus give a potential coordination site (see below).
elements.clean_text: The formula of 1 was written as {(NaCl)2[CuI 4(pz)4]3} to facilitate the understanding of its structure. The metallacrown [CuI 4(pz)4] has a neutral charge, and the sandwiched Cl- is charge-balanced by the linked Na+ at the periphery of a metallacrown to keep the overall charge neutral. As shown in a, four CuI and four pz- comprise a 12-membered metallomacrocycle, and the CuI atoms orient toward the center of a cavity, thus defining an inv-(12-MCCu(I),pz-4), which has a pseudo fourfold axis passing through the center of a metallacrown and gives an approximately square window. If weak CuI⋅⋅⋅Cl interaction is included, each CuI is in a T-shaped three-coordinate geometry completed by one Cl- and two N atoms of two different pz- ligands, making an average N-Cu-N angle of 158.2°. Such deviation from linearity should be pushed by Cl- in the perpendicular direction with respect to the N-Cu-N orientation. The T-shaped coordinate geometry of Cu(I) has been widely observed in a biological protein such as hemocyanin and also several Cu(I) coordination compounds. By contrast, the N-Cu-N angles in 7 tend to linearity [165.15(10)-179.60(11)°], which indicates that the stronger interaction between Cu and Cl/Br/I helps to stabilize the otherwise more constrained and thus less stable 12-MCCu(I),pz-4. The Cu-N bond distances vary from 1.868(5) to 1.882(5) Å. Four pz- ligands that are oriented in almost the same plane coincided with that built from four CuI centers. This geometry is substantially different from that of [Cu(dppz)]4 (Hdppz = 3,5-diphenylpyrazole) with every two dppz ligands projected above and below the Cu4 ring, forming a saddlelike molecule. Four nitro groups point to the outside of the metallacrown and thus give a potential coordination site (see below).

elements.content: (a) Structure of inv-[12-MCCu(I),pz-4] in 1. (b) Side view of the triple-decker structure built from three metallacrowns and the two sandwiched Cl– ions (color legend: purple, CuI; green, Cl; red, O; blue: N; and black: C). (c) Top view of the triple-decker structure along the pseudo fourfold axis with each metallacrown differed by colors.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Structure of inv-[12-MCCu(I),pz-4] in 1. (b) Side view of the triple-decker structure built from three metallacrowns and the two sandwiched Cl- ions (color legend: purple, CuI; green, Cl; red, O; blue: N; and black: C). (c) Top view of the triple-decker structure along the pseudo fourfold axis with each metallacrown differed by colors.

elements.content: Interestingly, two Cl– ions are separately sandwiched by every neighboring pair of 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 disks to form a triple-decker structure (b). The interior Cl– is unsymmetrically encapsulated, forming six CuI···Cl bonds with the interatomic distances of 2.593(2)–2.920(3) Å, which are significantly longer than the sums of copper and chlorine ionic radii (1.79 Å), but shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii (3.15 Å). The distance of two Cl– ions in one triple-decker is 4.29 Å, whereas each Cl– ion is not in the center of two layers with two different Cg···Cl distances of 1.07 and 2.15 Å (Cg is the centroid of four CuI ions in one metallacrown). Three 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 disks are parallel to each other without noticeable offset and are arranged in an equidistant fashion (d ≈ 3.2 Å) imposed by the crystallographic inversion center. From the top to the bottom, three layers are related to each other by the clockwise rotation of 38.5° (top → middle) and 51.2° (middle → bottom), respectively, which also indicates that the bottom layer is almost eclipsed with the top one (c) with a very small rotational angle of 0.3°. Formation of such planar square metallacrowns should be induced by the spherical Cl– template.
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, two Cl- ions are separately sandwiched by every neighboring pair of 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 disks to form a triple-decker structure (b). The interior Cl- is unsymmetrically encapsulated, forming six CuI⋅⋅⋅Cl bonds with the interatomic distances of 2.593(2)-2.920(3) Å, which are significantly longer than the sums of copper and chlorine ionic radii (1.79 Å), but shorter than the sum of their van der Waals radii (3.15 Å). The distance of two Cl- ions in one triple-decker is 4.29 Å, whereas each Cl- ion is not in the center of two layers with two different Cg⋅⋅⋅Cl distances of 1.07 and 2.15 Å (Cg is the centroid of four CuI ions in one metallacrown). Three 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 disks are parallel to each other without noticeable offset and are arranged in an equidistant fashion (d ~ 3.2 Å) imposed by the crystallographic inversion center. From the top to the bottom, three layers are related to each other by the clockwise rotation of 38.5° (top → middle) and 51.2° (middle → bottom), respectively, which also indicates that the bottom layer is almost eclipsed with the top one (c) with a very small rotational angle of 0.3°. Formation of such planar square metallacrowns should be induced by the spherical Cl- template.

elements.content: Within the metallacrown and a triple-decker, we found that the CuI···CuI separations are substantially longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii of CuI center (2.8 Å), indicating the absence of cuprophilic interaction. However, this supramolecular interaction was clearly visible between the adjacent triple-decker units with the CuI···CuI separation of 2.838(1) Å (Cu3···Cu4), which are very close to twice the van der Waals radii of CuI center, indicating the typical cuprophilic interaction. The triple-decker units are offset in the stacking in the crystalline state to give a 1D extended columnar structure with only two of the four CuI ions in one metallacrown involved in such a cuprophilic interaction (a). The noninnocent nitro groups also coordinate to Na+ [Na–O: 2.762(6)–2.963(7) Å] to extend the 1D chains to a 3D framework (b).
elements.clean_text: Within the metallacrown and a triple-decker, we found that the CuI⋅⋅⋅CuI separations are substantially longer than the sum of the van der Waals radii of CuI center (2.8 Å), indicating the absence of cuprophilic interaction. However, this supramolecular interaction was clearly visible between the adjacent triple-decker units with the CuI⋅⋅⋅CuI separation of 2.838(1) Å (Cu3⋅⋅⋅Cu4), which are very close to twice the van der Waals radii of CuI center, indicating the typical cuprophilic interaction. The triple-decker units are offset in the stacking in the crystalline state to give a 1D extended columnar structure with only two of the four CuI ions in one metallacrown involved in such a cuprophilic interaction (a). The noninnocent nitro groups also coordinate to Na+ [Na-O: 2.762(6)-2.963(7) Å] to extend the 1D chains to a 3D framework (b).

elements.content: (a) 1D chain structure built from triple-decker units through the cuprophilic interaction highlighted by the purple dashed lines. (b) 3D framework from Na-linked 1D chains viewed along the a axis. (Color legend: purple, CuI; green, Cl; red, O; blue: N; black: C; and yellow: Na).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) 1D chain structure built from triple-decker units through the cuprophilic interaction highlighted by the purple dashed lines. (b) 3D framework from Na-linked 1D chains viewed along the a axis. (Color legend: purple, CuI; green, Cl; red, O; blue: N; black: C; and yellow: Na).

elements.content: Although 1–6 crystallized into triclinic P1̅ space group and each unit cell contained one triple-decker molecule, the different radius and electronegativity of the halides imposed significant effects on the geometry of the triple-decker unit. As shown in , from NaCl to NaI (1–3) and KCl to KI (4–6), the interplanar distance (d 1) gradually becomes larger from 3.2 to 3.4 Å, consistent with the ionic radii of the halides. We also observed the consistent evolution rule in the CuI···CuI separation in metallacrown 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 and averaged Cu–N distances, that is, the larger radius of a halide leads to the larger size of metallacrown 12-MCCu(I),pz-4. All variations of metric parameters with respect to the halide radius clearly demonstrate the anion template effect. The formation of such anion-centered triple-decker structure should be dominated by the electronic properties of substituents on the pyrazolyl moiety. The peripheral electron-withdrawing nitro groups create the electron-deficient centers; therefore, the halides are sandwiched between them through electrostatic interactions to neutralize the local positive charges. This case is completely opposite in a double-decker {Ag­[(AuL)3]2}+ [HL = 3-(2-thienyl)-5-phenyl-1H-pyrazole], in which metallacrown 9-MCAu(I)-3 is electron-rich and can act as π-base to sandwich acidic AgI cation through the AgI···AuI metallophilic interaction. On the other hand, the existence of halides also makes tetranuclear 12-MCCu-4 crown planar instead of saddlelike conformation.
elements.clean_text: Although 1-6 crystallized into triclinic P1̅ space group and each unit cell contained one triple-decker molecule, the different radius and electronegativity of the halides imposed significant effects on the geometry of the triple-decker unit. As shown in , from NaCl to NaI (1-3) and KCl to KI (4-6), the interplanar distance (d 1) gradually becomes larger from 3.2 to 3.4 Å, consistent with the ionic radii of the halides. We also observed the consistent evolution rule in the CuI⋅⋅⋅CuI separation in metallacrown 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 and averaged Cu-N distances, that is, the larger radius of a halide leads to the larger size of metallacrown 12-MCCu(I),pz-4. All variations of metric parameters with respect to the halide radius clearly demonstrate the anion template effect. The formation of such anion-centered triple-decker structure should be dominated by the electronic properties of substituents on the pyrazolyl moiety. The peripheral electron-withdrawing nitro groups create the electron-deficient centers; therefore, the halides are sandwiched between them through electrostatic interactions to neutralize the local positive charges. This case is completely opposite in a double-decker {Ag[(AuL)3]2}+ [HL = 3-(2-thienyl)-5-phenyl-1H-pyrazole], in which metallacrown 9-MCAu(I)-3 is electron-rich and can act as π-base to sandwich acidic AgI cation through the AgI⋅⋅⋅AuI metallophilic interaction. On the other hand, the existence of halides also makes tetranuclear 12-MCCu-4 crown planar instead of saddlelike conformation.

elements.content: Because of the strongest electronegativity and the smallest radius of F– among the halides, we could not isolate the F–-centered triple-decker motif but only obtained a hexanuclear cluster {[F@CuII 6(pz)9(OH)2(DMF)4(H2O)]·2DMF, 7} in the presence of NaF, in which all Cu atoms have a +2 oxidation state. The structure of 7 revealed using X-ray crystallography on a single crystal shows a hexanuclear trigonal prism motif with a pair of parallel [CuII 3(pz)3(OH)] trigons clamped by three pz bridges. An F– ion is sandwiched between a pair of [CuII 3(pz)3(OH)] trigons with the Cu–F distances of 2.218(4)–2.784(4) Å. This structure is very similar to that of [F@CuII 6(L1)6(L2)3(OH)2] (HL1 = pyrazole; HL2 = 3,5-diphenyl-pyrazole). We, therefore, will not discuss much about the structure of 7 because of such similarities, which is shown in Figure S1; however, this result illustrated that the size and electronegativity of the halides have important influence on the formation of analogues to 1–6.
elements.clean_text: Because of the strongest electronegativity and the smallest radius of F- among the halides, we could not isolate the F--centered triple-decker motif but only obtained a hexanuclear cluster {[F@CuII 6(pz)9(OH)2(DMF)4(H2O)]⋅2DMF, 7} in the presence of NaF, in which all Cu atoms have a +2 oxidation state. The structure of 7 revealed using X-ray crystallography on a single crystal shows a hexanuclear trigonal prism motif with a pair of parallel [CuII 3(pz)3(OH)] trigons clamped by three pz bridges. An F- ion is sandwiched between a pair of [CuII 3(pz)3(OH)] trigons with the Cu-F distances of 2.218(4)-2.784(4) Å. This structure is very similar to that of [F@CuII 6(L1)6(L2)3(OH)2] (HL1 = pyrazole; HL2 = 3,5-diphenyl-pyrazole). We, therefore, will not discuss much about the structure of 7 because of such similarities, which is shown in Figure S1; however, this result illustrated that the size and electronegativity of the halides have important influence on the formation of analogues to 1-6.

elements.content: We studied the solution behaviors of such interesting family using high-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESI-MS). Crystals of 1–6 were dissolved in DMF, diluted with methanol, and then transferred to the gas phase using electrospray ionization (ESI). As shown in , there are a series of singly charged envelopes in the m/z range of 1000–3000 in the negative-mode ESI-MS of 1–3, whereas no signals were observed for 4–6, which may be detected under the mass spectrometry conditions. Comparing the simulated and experimentally observed isotope distributions (Figure S2), we were able to attribute these predominant species in the ESI-MS of 1–3 to a general formula of [Cu x (pz) y ] (x = 5, 6, or 7, y = x – 1, x or x + 1). For 1, the most dominated peak at m/z = 1343.6977 (1a) was assigned to [Cu6(pz)6Cl2H­(DMF)3]−, which could be seen as a complete 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 metallacrown plus another half of it, that is, a half of the parent triple-decker metallacrown. Similarly, the dominated peaks of 2 and 3 at m/z = 1353.6189 (2a) and 1401.6108 (3b) can also be assigned to a half of triple-decker metallacrowns with the formulae of [NaCu6(pz)7Br­(CH3OH)­(H2O)3]− and [NaCu6(pz)7I­(CH3OH)­(H2O)3]−, respectively. The detailed assignments for other species in solutions of 1–3 are listed in Table S4. On the basis of the X-ray structures and ESI-MS analysis, we rationalized that the embryonic 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 metallacrowns in solution are the most possible building blocks for the assembly of triple-decker motifs under the induction of alkali halide.
elements.clean_text:
Solution Behaviors of 1-6 

We studied the solution behaviors of such interesting family using high-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESI-MS). Crystals of 1-6 were dissolved in DMF, diluted with methanol, and then transferred to the gas phase using electrospray ionization (ESI). As shown in , there are a series of singly charged envelopes in the m/z range of 1000-3000 in the negative-mode ESI-MS of 1-3, whereas no signals were observed for 4-6, which may be detected under the mass spectrometry conditions. Comparing the simulated and experimentally observed isotope distributions (Figure S2), we were able to attribute these predominant species in the ESI-MS of 1-3 to a general formula of [Cu x (pz) y ] (x = 5, 6, or 7, y = x - 1, x or x + 1). For 1, the most dominated peak at m/z = 1343.6977 (1a) was assigned to [Cu6(pz)6Cl2H(DMF)3]-, which could be seen as a complete 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 metallacrown plus another half of it, that is, a half of the parent triple-decker metallacrown. Similarly, the dominated peaks of 2 and 3 at m/z = 1353.6189 (2a) and 1401.6108 (3b) can also be assigned to a half of triple-decker metallacrowns with the formulae of [NaCu6(pz)7Br(CH3OH)(H2O)3]- and [NaCu6(pz)7I(CH3OH)(H2O)3]-, respectively. The detailed assignments for other species in solutions of 1-3 are listed in Table S4. On the basis of the X-ray structures and ESI-MS analysis, we rationalized that the embryonic 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 metallacrowns in solution are the most possible building blocks for the assembly of triple-decker motifs under the induction of alkali halide.

elements.content: Negative-mode HRESI-MS of 1–6 dissolved in DMF/CH3OH.
elements.clean_text: 3  Negative-mode HRESI-MS of 1-6 dissolved in DMF/CH3OH.

elements.content: The electrochemical properties of compounds 4, 5, and 6 were investigated (scan rate: 100 mV s–1) in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution by fabricating them as carbon paste electrodes (CPEs). As shown in , the cyclic voltammetry (CV) of 4-, 5-, and 6-CPEs reveals a couple of similar redox peaks (I/I′) in the sweep range between −0.3 and 0.3 V, which is attributed to the redox process of CuI/CuII. Moreover, their redox peak potentials are located at 0.082 and −0.063 V, 0.103 and −0.056 V, and 0.118 and −0.049 V for 4-, 5-, and 6-CPE, respectively, indicating that the oxidation ability should follow an order of 6 > 5 > 4. The redox potential of 4–6 should be exclusively governed by the electronegativity of the halides (Cl, Br, and I). For example, chloride has the strongest electronegativity that causes CuI to be oxidized easily; thus, compound 4 has the weakest oxidation ability. Furthermore, CV of 6-CPE also exhibits another pair of redox peaks in the potential range of 0.3–0.8 V, which is ascribed to the redox process I–/I3 –.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemistry and Electrocatalytic Properties of 4, 5, and 6 

The electrochemical properties of compounds 4, 5, and 6 were investigated (scan rate: 100 mV s-1) in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution by fabricating them as carbon paste electrodes (CPEs). As shown in , the cyclic voltammetry (CV) of 4-, 5-, and 6-CPEs reveals a couple of similar redox peaks (I/I') in the sweep range between -0.3 and 0.3 V, which is attributed to the redox process of CuI/CuII. Moreover, their redox peak potentials are located at 0.082 and -0.063 V, 0.103 and -0.056 V, and 0.118 and -0.049 V for 4-, 5-, and 6-CPE, respectively, indicating that the oxidation ability should follow an order of 6 > 5 > 4. The redox potential of 4-6 should be exclusively governed by the electronegativity of the halides (Cl, Br, and I). For example, chloride has the strongest electronegativity that causes CuI to be oxidized easily; thus, compound 4 has the weakest oxidation ability. Furthermore, CV of 6-CPE also exhibits another pair of redox peaks in the potential range of 0.3-0.8 V, which is ascribed to the redox process I-/I3 -.

elements.content: Successive CVs of 4-, 5-, and 6-CPE in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at the scan rate of 100 mV s–1.
elements.clean_text: 4  Successive CVs of 4-, 5-, and 6-CPE in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at the scan rate of 100 mV s-1.

elements.content: With the knowledge that direct electroreduction of nitrite requires a large overpotential at most electrode surfaces, it is essential to seek appropriate intermediates to catalyze the reduction of nitrite. As shown in , all 4, 5, and 6 exhibit excellent performances for the electrochemical reduction of nitrite. The electrocatalytic currents in continuous CVs of 4-, 5-, and 6-CPE in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution increase stepwise with successive additions of nitrite from 0 to 40 mM (scan rate: 100 mV s–1), corresponding to the sensitive and rapid nitrite reduction at the electrodes. A large amount of gas bubbles (NO), according to 3 HN O 2 = HN O 3 + 2 NO ↑ + H 2 O were generated on the electrode surface (Figure S3), indicating a superior electrocatalytic activity of 4, 5, and 6 toward the reduction of nitrite. We also compared the electrocatalytic activities of 4, 5, and 6 for the nitrite reduction by calculating the catalytic efficiency (CAT). The results showed that the electrocatalytic activity followed an order of 5 > 4 > 6 (Figure S4).
elements.clean_text: With the knowledge that direct electroreduction of nitrite requires a large overpotential at most electrode surfaces, it is essential to seek appropriate intermediates to catalyze the reduction of nitrite. As shown in , all 4, 5, and 6 exhibit excellent performances for the electrochemical reduction of nitrite. The electrocatalytic currents in continuous CVs of 4-, 5-, and 6-CPE in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution increase stepwise with successive additions of nitrite from 0 to 40 mM (scan rate: 100 mV s-1), corresponding to the sensitive and rapid nitrite reduction at the electrodes. A large amount of gas bubbles (NO), according to   1     3 HN   O   2   = HN   O   3   + 2 NO ↑ +   H   2   O    were generated on the electrode surface (Figure S3), indicating a superior electrocatalytic activity of 4, 5, and 6 toward the reduction of nitrite. We also compared the electrocatalytic activities of 4, 5, and 6 for the nitrite reduction by calculating the catalytic efficiency (CAT). The results showed that the electrocatalytic activity followed an order of 5 > 4 > 6 (Figure S4).

elements.content: Successive CVs of (a) 4-CPE, (b) 5-CPE, and (c) 6-CPE in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution containing 0–40 mM NaNO2 solution. Scan rate: 100 mV s–1.
elements.clean_text: 5  Successive CVs of (a) 4-CPE, (b) 5-CPE, and (c) 6-CPE in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution containing 0-40 mM NaNO2 solution. Scan rate: 100 mV s-1.

elements.content: Furthermore, the electrocatalytic activity of 4, 5, and 6 to the reduction of H2O2 was also tested under similar conditions. As depicted in Figure S5, the gradual addition of H2O2 to the electrolyte results in a slow increase in the cathodic peak currents for 4-, 5-, and 6-CPE, whereas the corresponding anodic peak current decreases tardily. Moreover, upon the addition of H2O2, the reduction peak currents were shifted toward more negative potentials, suggesting that a kinetic limitation exists in the reaction between 4, 5, and 6 and H2O2. The CATs of 4, 5, and 6 showed that 5 has better electrocatalytic performance than 4 and 6.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, the electrocatalytic activity of 4, 5, and 6 to the reduction of H2O2 was also tested under similar conditions. As depicted in Figure S5, the gradual addition of H2O2 to the electrolyte results in a slow increase in the cathodic peak currents for 4-, 5-, and 6-CPE, whereas the corresponding anodic peak current decreases tardily. Moreover, upon the addition of H2O2, the reduction peak currents were shifted toward more negative potentials, suggesting that a kinetic limitation exists in the reaction between 4, 5, and 6 and H2O2. The CATs of 4, 5, and 6 showed that 5 has better electrocatalytic performance than 4 and 6.

elements.content:
Regarding the electrochemical stability of 4, 5, and 6, we selected 5 as a representative to elucidate the stability during electrochemical process in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution.

We studied the electrochemical stability of 5 in CPE by using 35 electrochemical cycles between −0.3 and 0.8 V in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at a scan rate of 100 mV s–1 and under an N2 atmosphere. As shown in Figure S6, the redox peaks corresponding to CuI/CuII and I–/I3 – remain unchanged including the potential and the current after 35 electrochemical cycles, which clearly indicate that 5 in CPE is rather stable during the CV process when using 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution as the electrolyte.

After 35 electrochemical cycles, we recollected the CV of the electrolyte solution by changing 5-CPE to a bare CPE (Figure S7a) and a bare glassy carbon electrode (Figure S7b) and compared them with the CV of the blank electrolyte solution. The CVs of the blank electrolyte solution and that of the electrolyte solution after 35 cycles are very similar (Figure S7c), which suggests that there are no additional active species dissolved into the solution from 5-CPE. We also compared the CV of 5-CPE with the above results, and the characteristic redox peaks of 5-CPE were not observed in them (Figure S7d). All tests consistently supported the stability of 5-CPE in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution.

To further prove the electrochemical stability of 5 under continuous CV scans in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution, we performed a long-term chronoamperometric test using 5-CPE. Figure S8 shows the amperometric response of 5-CPE versus the time recorded at 1.3 V for 6200 s. In this time scale, no noticeable change in the oxidation current is detected for 5-CPE, but only very slight oxidation current decay (<5%) was found after 6200 s, which demonstrated that 5-CPE is fairly stable in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution.

To prove that the redox signals are coming from 5 rather than “free” copper ion in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution, we recorded the CV of 0.256 mM CuSO4 in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution (scan rate: 100 mV s–1) using bare CPE. Only one anodic peak located at 0.048 was detected, which was clearly different from that of 5-CPE (Figure S9), illustrating that the redox peaks in the CV of 5-CPE are not electrochemically responded from “free” copper ion.

We also immersed 5 in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution for 5 h while taking pictures periodically. As depicted in Figure S10, the color and morphology of the microcrystalline sample of 5 remained unchanged after 5 h, and especially, the H2SO4 aqueous solution was pellucid and colorless. The stability of 5 in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution was also proved by comparing powder X-ray diffraction patterns (Figure S11) and IR results (Figure S12). In all, 5 should be fairly stable in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution, which was in accordance with the results obtained above.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Stability

Regarding the electrochemical stability of 4, 5, and 6, we selected 5 as a representative to elucidate the stability during electrochemical process in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution.  (1) We studied the electrochemical stability of 5 in CPE by using 35 electrochemical cycles between -0.3 and 0.8 V in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at a scan rate of 100 mV s-1 and under an N2 atmosphere. As shown in Figure S6, the redox peaks corresponding to CuI/CuII and I-/I3 - remain unchanged including the potential and the current after 35 electrochemical cycles, which clearly indicate that 5 in CPE is rather stable during the CV process when using 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution as the electrolyte.   (2) After 35 electrochemical cycles, we recollected the CV of the electrolyte solution by changing 5-CPE to a bare CPE (Figure S7a) and a bare glassy carbon electrode (Figure S7b) and compared them with the CV of the blank electrolyte solution. The CVs of the blank electrolyte solution and that of the electrolyte solution after 35 cycles are very similar (Figure S7c), which suggests that there are no additional active species dissolved into the solution from 5-CPE. We also compared the CV of 5-CPE with the above results, and the characteristic redox peaks of 5-CPE were not observed in them (Figure S7d). All tests consistently supported the stability of 5-CPE in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution.   (3) To further prove the electrochemical stability of 5 under continuous CV scans in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution, we performed a long-term chronoamperometric test using 5-CPE. Figure S8 shows the amperometric response of 5-CPE versus the time recorded at 1.3 V for 6200 s. In this time scale, no noticeable change in the oxidation current is detected for 5-CPE, but only very slight oxidation current decay (<5%) was found after 6200 s, which demonstrated that 5-CPE is fairly stable in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution.   (4) To prove that the redox signals are coming from 5 rather than "free" copper ion in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution, we recorded the CV of 0.256 mM CuSO4 in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution (scan rate: 100 mV s-1) using bare CPE. Only one anodic peak located at 0.048 was detected, which was clearly different from that of 5-CPE (Figure S9), illustrating that the redox peaks in the CV of 5-CPE are not electrochemically responded from "free" copper ion.   (5) We also immersed 5 in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution for 5 h while taking pictures periodically. As depicted in Figure S10, the color and morphology of the microcrystalline sample of 5 remained unchanged after 5 h, and especially, the H2SO4 aqueous solution was pellucid and colorless. The stability of 5 in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution was also proved by comparing powder X-ray diffraction patterns (Figure S11) and IR results (Figure S12). In all, 5 should be fairly stable in 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution, which was in accordance with the results obtained above.

elements.content: The UV–vis absorption spectrum for compound 6 was characterized in the solid state by using the diffuse reflectance mode (Figure S13). The absorption maximum at 302 nm originated from ligand-centered (LC) π → π* transitions and that around 450 nm may be from a halogen-to-metal charge transfer process. The solid-state photoluminescence spectra for 6 and Hpz were recorded at room temperature, as shown in a. The emission maximum centered at 464 nm was detected under the 410 nm UV irradiation and exhibits characteristics similar to Hpz (λem = 470 nm) with a 6 nm blue shift, indicating that the photoluminescence of 6 is mainly from the ligand-based excitation state. The absolute quantum yield of 6 in the solid state is approximately 0.6%.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Behaviors and Sensing Properties

The UV-vis absorption spectrum for compound 6 was characterized in the solid state by using the diffuse reflectance mode (Figure S13). The absorption maximum at 302 nm originated from ligand-centered (LC) π → π* transitions and that around 450 nm may be from a halogen-to-metal charge transfer process. The solid-state photoluminescence spectra for 6 and Hpz were recorded at room temperature, as shown in a. The emission maximum centered at 464 nm was detected under the 410 nm UV irradiation and exhibits characteristics similar to Hpz (λem = 470 nm) with a 6 nm blue shift, indicating that the photoluminescence of 6 is mainly from the ligand-based excitation state. The absolute quantum yield of 6 in the solid state is approximately 0.6%.

elements.content: (a) Solid-state photoluminescence spectra of 6 and Hpz. (b) Fluorescence intensity of 6 upon the addition of different concentrations of Ag+ (from top to bottom: 0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30, 0.35, 0.40, 0.45, 0.50, 0.55, and 0.60 mM) in H2O.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Solid-state photoluminescence spectra of 6 and Hpz. (b) Fluorescence intensity of 6 upon the addition of different concentrations of Ag+ (from top to bottom: 0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30, 0.35, 0.40, 0.45, 0.50, 0.55, and 0.60 mM) in H2O.

elements.content: Being inspired by a previous work on the fluorescence sensing properties of metallacrowns, the samples of 6 (5 mg) were immersed into the 5 mL aqueous solution containing different metal ions (Zn2+, Mg2+, K+, Hg2+, Cr3+, Cd2+, Al3+, Co2+, and Ag+; 1 mM) and then ultrasonicated for 5 min to form a suspension for luminescent sensing studies. We found that the addition of Co2+ ions hardly changes the emission intensity, whereas the addition of Hg2+ ions can slightly enhance the emission intensity. For Zn2+, Mg2+, K+, Cr3+, Al3+, and Cd2+, only marginal quenching effect on the emission intensity was detected (Figure S14). By contrast, we found that Ag+ ions can dramatically quench the luminescence at 508 nm, which indicates that 6 can selectively sense Ag+ ions through luminescence quenching. It should be noted that the red-shifted emission of 6 in water suspension with respect to that in the solid state is most likely caused by the formation of hydrogen bonds between the −NO2 group and the water molecule. We thus examined the quantitative response of 6 toward Ag+ by fluorometric titrations (b). The emission intensity of emulsion of 6 linearly decreased upon increasing the Ag+ concentration from 0 to 0.6 mM (Figure S15). The limit of detection (LOD) was determined to be 114 μM for probe 6 on the basis of the signal-to-noise ratio, S/N = 3. The pH values of the suspension are 6.31 and 5.81 before and after the fluorometric titrations, respectively. The decreased pH value after the addition of Ag+ ions is induced by more acidic AgNO3 aqueous solution (pH = 5.47 for 10 mM AgNO3 aqueous solution). We also checked the recyclability of this sensor; unfortunately, it cannot work in the second cycle, which may be caused by strong interaction between silver ions and the nitro group (Figure S16). The UV–vis spectrum for the emulsion of 6 was measured by adding different concentrations of Ag+ (Figure S17), and the red shift from 425 to 485 nm was detected with the addition of Ag+ ions from 0 to 0.25 mM, implying that the mechanism of the quenching effect of 6 by Ag+ may be a ligand-to-metal charge-transfer process, induced by the specific coordination interaction of Ag+ and the peripheral NO2 groups. We also considered the halogen effects on the sensing behaviors of Ag+ by the fluorescence titration for 4 and 5 under the same conditions (Figure S20). On the basis of the calculated LOD (Figure S21), we found that 4 and 5 have the much lower LOD of 65.6 and 74.4 μM, respectively.

We found that the addition of Co2+ ions hardly changes the emission intensity, whereas the addition of Hg2+ ions can slightly enhance the emission intensity. For Zn2+, Mg2+, K+, Cr3+, Al3+, and Cd2+, only marginal quenching effect on the emission intensity was detected (Figure S14). By contrast, we found that Ag+ ions can dramatically quench the luminescence at 508 nm, which indicates that 6 can selectively sense Ag+ ions through luminescence quenching. We thus examined the quantitative response of 6 toward Ag+ by fluorometric titrations (b). The emission intensity of emulsion of 6 linearly decreased upon increasing the Ag+ concentration from 0 to 0.6 mM (Figure S15). The limit of detection (LOD) was determined to be 114 μM for probe 6 on the basis of the signal-to-noise ratio, S/N = 3. The pH values of the suspension are 6.31 and 5.81 before and after the fluorometric titrations, respectively. The decreased pH value after the addition of Ag+ ions is induced by more acidic AgNO3 aqueous solution (pH = 5.47 for 10 mM AgNO3 aqueous solution). The UV-vis spectrum for the emulsion of 6 was measured by adding different concentrations of Ag+ (Figure S17), and the red shift from 425 to 485 nm was detected with the addition of Ag+ ions from 0 to 0.25 mM, implying that the mechanism of the quenching effect of 6 by Ag+ may be a ligand-to-metal charge-transfer process, induced by the specific coordination interaction of Ag+ and the peripheral NO2 groups. elements.content: In summary, we have isolated and structurally characterized a series of 12-MCCu(I),pz-4-based triple-decker complexes with different trapped alkali halides acting as templates. They have very similar motif but with some structural variations dependent on the radius and electronegativity of halides. HRESI-MS revealed that the possible building blocks for such triple-decker motifs are 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 metallacrowns and that the assembly should be in a stepwise fashion. Moreover, compounds 4, 5, and 6 proved to be excellent bifunctional materials as electrocatalysts toward the reduction of nitrite and selective “turn-off” sensors for Ag­(I) in water. These findings deepen our understanding of the design and synthesis of multifunctional metallacrown-type compounds and their multiple-decker complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have isolated and structurally characterized a series of 12-MCCu(I),pz-4-based triple-decker complexes with different trapped alkali halides acting as templates. They have very similar motif but with some structural variations dependent on the radius and electronegativity of halides. HRESI-MS revealed that the possible building blocks for such triple-decker motifs are 12-MCCu(I),pz-4 metallacrowns and that the assembly should be in a stepwise fashion. Moreover, compounds 4, 5, and 6 proved to be excellent bifunctional materials as electrocatalysts toward the reduction of nitrite and selective "turn-off" sensors for Ag(I) in water. These findings deepen our understanding of the design and synthesis of multifunctional metallacrown-type compounds and their multiple-decker complexes.

cln_elements.content: The UV–vis absorption spectrum for compound 6 was characterized in the solid state by using the diffuse reflectance mode (Figure S13). The absorption maximum at 302 nm originated from ligand-centered (LC) π → π* transitions and that around 450 nm may be from a halogen-to-metal charge transfer process. The solid-state photoluminescence spectra for 6 and Hpz were recorded at room temperature, as shown in a. The emission maximum centered at 464 nm was detected under the 410 nm UV irradiation and exhibits characteristics similar to Hpz (λem = 470 nm) with a 6 nm blue shift, indicating that the photoluminescence of 6 is mainly from the ligand-based excitation state. The absolute quantum yield of 6 in the solid state is approximately 0.6%.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Behaviors and Sensing Properties

The UV-vis absorption spectrum for compound 6 was characterized in the solid state by using the diffuse reflectance mode (Figure S13). The absorption maximum at 302 nm originated from ligand-centered (LC) π → π* transitions and that around 450 nm may be from a halogen-to-metal charge transfer process. The solid-state photoluminescence spectra for 6 and Hpz were recorded at room temperature, as shown in a. The emission maximum centered at 464 nm was detected under the 410 nm UV irradiation and exhibits characteristics similar to Hpz (λem = 470 nm) with a 6 nm blue shift, indicating that the photoluminescence of 6 is mainly from the ligand-based excitation state. The absolute quantum yield of 6 in the solid state is approximately 0.6%.

peak spectrum.condition: room temperature, under 410 nm UV irradiation

cln_elements.content:
Selected Metric Parameters in the Crystal Structures of <bold>1–6</bold> <xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref>

Black ball is the centroid of every four CuI ions in one metallacrown. Green ball is the halogen ion and purple ball is the CuI ion.
